Graphical abstract The catalytic CO oxidation on Fe-adsorbed h-BN includes O2 adsorption, electron transfer, CO adsorption, oxygen transfer, and CO2 desorption. The rate determining step is the first oxygen transfer, with a barrier of 1.18 eV on V N-Fe (Fe atom is adsorbed on N vacancy). Conversion of CO into CO2 is a prototypical reaction in heterogeneous catalysis and is extensively studied to explore the underlying mechanisms of related reaction. A detailed mechanism exploration was carried out for CO oxidation catalyzed by single Fe atom adsorbed hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) at room temperature. DFT calculations demonstrate the enhancement of catalytic activity of h-BN for CO oxidation upon Fe-adsorbing. The substitution of iron significantly decreases the energy difference between the HOMO and LUMO in h-BN. The positively charged Fe atom in dopant favors the capture of O2 molecule and serves as the catalytic active site for CO oxidation reaction. Energetically, the adsorbed Fe atom prefers to reside in N vacancy (V N-Fe) rather than B vacancy, with the energy barriers for the generation of two CO2 molecules are 1.18 eV and 0.76 eV, respectively. The rate determining step is the first oxygen transfer, as attributes to the significant charge transfer from Fe-adsorbed h-BN to O2. The enhanced catalytic activity implies that Fe-adsorbed h-BN has potential application for the development of low-cost, non-toxic monoatomic catalysts. Keywords h-BN Fe-adsorbing Single atom catalyst CO Oxidation Density Functional Theory Introduction CO oxidation reaction plays an important role in controlling the increasingly serious environmental pollution caused by CO emission from automobiles and fossil fuels combustion [1–6]. CO combines easily with hemoglobin in human blood to form carboxyhemoglobin, which makes hemoglobin lose the ability to transport oxygen, causing tissue suffocation and death in severe cases [7,8]. CO oxidation has become one of the most studied reactions in past few decades. The most critical issue is to find an efficient catalyst [9], which is usually doped with noble metals (such as Au, Ag, Pt, Rh, Ru, Pd, and Ir) [10–25]. In experiments, noble metals are also used to enhance the performance of catalytic CO oxidation [26–28]. But several problems, such as limited natural resources, high cost, and high reaction temperature, hampers their large-scale application in industrial production. Non-noble metal-based catalysts have attracted considerable research interest in recent years due to their low-cost and highly activity [29–37]. The low-cost Fe-anchored graphene and graphene oxide can be served as a promising green catalyst for low-temperature CO oxidation [31,38,39]. Such catalysts are defined as single-atom catalysts (SACs) [40–44], which maximizes the metal atom efficiency. SACs have become a hot topic owing to their significant advantages of maximized atomic utilization, uniform active sites with excellent stability and selectivity, as well as distinctly improved catalytic activity over conventional metal nanoparticles. Although h-BN has similar geometrical structure to graphene, its unique physical and chemical properties are the focus of research [45–50]. In particular, h-BN has high chemical stability, and it maintains the integrity of the material itself even up to 1000 K [51,52]. The doped h-BN by single metal atom (such as Co, Ru, Cu) [9,53,54] has exhibited highly activity in the CO oxidation reaction. Totally, three possible mechanisms for CO oxidation were designed, including the Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism, the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism, and the Termolecular Eley–Rideal (TER) mechanism [9]. The Co-doped h-BN catalyzes the CO oxidation via activating the O-O bond under the ER mechanism, with the reaction energy barrier of 0.53 eV [55]. The catalysis for CO oxidation on B-vacancy of Fe-doped h-BN is divided into two steps (CO + O2 → CO2 + O*, CO + O* → CO2) based on the Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism. The corresponding energy barriers for CO2 generation in two different steps are 0.56 eV and 0.61 eV, respectively [29]. These works provide valuable information about the structure-activity relationship of h-BN dopant and demonstrate the potential application of doped h-BN SACs as the efficient CO oxidation catalyst. Based on the above findings, Fe-adsorbed h-BN SAC is expected to be effective for CO oxidation. The aim of this study is to explore the detailed mechanism of CO oxidation for both N-vacancy (V N-Fe) and B-vacancy (V B-Fe) dopant. Although Fe-adsorbed h-BN is a low-cost and high activity catalyst, there are still four questions to be solved: 1) Does the spin multiplicity of Fe affect the stability and the efficiency of the structure? 2) Which vacancy is better, V N or V B for CO oxidation? 3) Which molecule prefers to be adsorbed on the dopant at first, O2 or CO? 4) Which one corresponds to the rate-determining step? The computational methods are given in Section 2. The results and discussion are collected in Section 3. Finally, a brief conclusion is summarized in Section 4. Computational Methods The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out employing the hybrid Becke, three-parameter, Lee-Yang-Parr exchange correlation functional (B3LYP) with the 6-31 G (d) basis set using the Gaussian 09 program [56]. The IR spectra are employed to determine whether the optimized stationary points correspond to the local minima or the transition states on the potential energy surfaces (PES). In addition, the relationship between the transition states and the reactants/products is established by using intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) [57] analyses. The charge transfer, electron population, and the bonding characteristics along with the CO oxidation are discussed with the natural bond orbital (NBO) analyses [58]. The nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) data are obtained using the gauge independent atomic orbital (GIAO) [59,60] method. The magnetic shielding tensor (σ) of the primary atoms and the NMR spin-spin coupling constant (n J (A, B): n refers to the number of bonds connecting nuclei A and B) are determined. The substitution energy (E sub) is calculated according to E sub = − [E BN-Fe + E N/B − E BN − E Fe]. Where, E BN-Fe denotes the total energy of Fe-adsorbed h-BN; E N/B refers to the energy of N/B atom; E BN is the energy of h-BN; E Fe presents the energy of Fe atom. The binding energy (E b) is defined as E b= − [E BNFe-M − E BNFe − E M]. In this definition, E BNFe-M refers to the total energy of the system when the small gas molecule (O2 or CO) is adsorbed on Fe-adsorbed h-BN; E BNFe denotes the energy of Fe-adsorbed h-BN; E M is the energy of small gas molecules. A larger E b represents an energetically more favorable process. All the energies are corrected by the zero-point vibrational energy (ZPE), which is offered along with the IR spectra. Results and discussion The Geometry and Stability of V N-Fe and V B-Fe Fig. 1 presents the primary geometrical parameters of h-BN, V N-Fe, and V B-Fe. For N-vacancy dopant, the Fe-B bond length is 1.915 Å, distinctly longer as compared to the N-B distance (1.448 Å) in h-BN; the B2FeB3 angle is 85.4°, less than the B2N3B3 angle (120.0°) in h-BN. Strong steric repulsion between Fe and three around B atoms contributes to these variations. In case of B-vacancy dopant, V B-Fe, the Fe-N bond length (1.835 Å) is longer than the B-N bond in h-BN and shorter than the Fe-B distance in V N-Fe. The N2FeN3 angle is 104.9°, locates between the B2N3B3 angle in h-BN and the B2FeB3 angle in V N-Fe. Therefore, the Fe atom locates out of the h-BN plane in both dopants. The difference of atomic radius between Fe and vacancy contributes predominantly to the structural variation upon Fe-adsorbing. Fig. 2 (a) presents the substitution energy (E sub) of Fe to form doublet, quartet, sextet, and octet V N-Fe dopant as well as the NBO charges on Fe atom. The calculated minimum E sub is 12.35 eV in doublet V N-Fe as well as the maximum NBO charge of Fe in octet V N-Fe is 0.598. This E sub is larger than those of Ru and S [53,61], indicating a stronger interaction between the adsorbed Fe and the N-vacancy. The E sub of Fe to generate doublet, quartet, sextet, and octet V B-Fe as well as NBO charge of Fe atom are shown in Fig. (2 b). It is found that the minimum E sub is 7.53 eV and the maximum NBO charge of Fe atom is 1.534 in sextet V B-Fe. Generally, the energy difference between the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) (E L-H) is an index for the stability of the material. E L-H value reflects the probability of electron transfer, the bonding characteristics, and the chemical activity. It has been reported that large positive charges populated on metal atom favors the subsequent O2 activation [62–64]. Fig. (2 c) shows that E L-H decreases distinctly from 6.58 eV in h-BN to 3.88/3.59 eV in V N-Fe/ V B-Fe, indicating the enhancement of the activity upon Fe adsorbing. The catalytic activity of h-BN is greatly enhanced upon Fe adsorbing for both N and B vacancies. Therefore, the sextet dopants are selected as the potential candidates for CO oxidation. Adsorption of O2 and CO molecules on V N-Fe and V B-Fe CO oxidation includes the reactant adsorption (CO and O2) and the product desorption (CO2) on V N-Fe/ V B-Fe. The small binding energy (E b) of h-BN with CO/O2 (0.02/0.10 eV) indicates the low activity of h-BN to further catalyze CO oxidation. This is consistent with the previous explorations [61,65,66]. The E b of O2 with V N-Fe/ V B-Fe is 2.69/1.03 eV, which is increased distinctly as compared to that of CO (Fig. 2d). The above results indicate that O2 combines tightly with V N-Fe/ V B-Fe than CO. The adsorption of O2 should be followed by CO. Fig. 3 shows the optimized geometrical structures, with the bond lengths of O-O/C-O labeled. The length of the combined C-O bond is 1.159/1.136 Å, which is almost equal to that of gaseous CO (1.138 Å). However, the O-O bond length extends by over 0.1 Å upon adsorption than gaseous O2 (1.215 Å), which should attribute to the charge transfer (0.49 e-/0.41 e-) from dopant to O2. This is a typical peroxide state [67]. Mechanisms for CO Oxidation The CO oxidation mechanism mainly includes O2 adsorption, electron reorganization, CO adsorption, oxygen transfer, and CO2 desorption. The detailed process is discussed below. CO Oxidation on V N-Fe The triplet O2 is adsorbed on the V N-Fe template, generating the quartet N-i, initiating the entire catalytic CO oxidation reaction (Fig. 4 ). Geometrically, the distances of two O atoms with Fe atom in N-i are 1.804 and 1.852 Å (Table 1 ), respectively. The bond lengths of Fe-B1, Fe-B2, and Fe-B3 increase by ∼ 0.1 Å (from 1.914, 1.915, and 1.915 Å to 2.021, 1.999, and 2.018 Å, respectively), indicating the strong interaction between dopant and O2. About 0.76 NBO electrons are transferred from V N-Fe to O2, and the transferred electrons mainly derive from the Fe atom in V N-Fe (Fig. 5 a). The O2 adsorption is an exothermic reaction with the energy decline by 2.69 eV (Fig. 4a). The adsorption of CO generates N-ii, with the distance between CO and O2 of 2.905 Å and the bond lengths of Fe-OA/Fe-OB extended by ∼ 0.10 Å (Table 1). However, the effect on the geometrical parameters of the dopant is slight. CO adsorption is an exothermic process by 0.54 eV (Fig. 4a). There are about 0.34 NBO electrons transferred between the dopant and the adsorbed CO/O2 molecules, and the transferred electrons mainly derives from the Fe atom (NBO charge of Fe from 0.77 to 0.43) in V N-Fe (Fig. 5a). The OB transfers to CO with N-iii formation and generating the first CO2. The process occurs exothermically by -2.44 eV with an activation energy barrier of 1.18 eV (Fig. 4a). The barrier is not high and the previous steps are all exothermic reactions with reaction heat of -3.23 eV. This barrier is lower compared to Pt/4N-graphene (1.81 eV) [68] and Cu-BN (1.91 eV) [69]. Low activation energy barrier and high exothermicity are beneficial to accelerate reaction rate, which indicates that V N-Fe is an efficient catalyst for CO oxidation. For N-iii, the distance between the generated CO2 and the remaining O atom (OA) is 3.061 Å, indicating the weak interaction between CO2 and dopant (Table 1). The distance between OA and Fe atom is shortened by 0.269 Å, indicating the strengthening between OA and Fe atom (Table 1). There are –0.55 NBO electrons located on OA in N-iii (Fig. 5a). The C-O stretching signal is blue-shifted from 2096.9 to 2428.2 cm-1 in N-iii (Table 2 ). The negatively charged OA favors the approaching of the second CO molecule and further oxidation. The subsequent reaction mechanism is discussed in the following two paths: (1) the generated CO2 desorption occurs before the second CO adsorption; (2) the second CO adsorption is followed by the generated CO2 desorption. In path 1, the first CO2 desorption is an endothermic reaction with reaction energy of 0.17 eV (Fig. 4a). No distinct change is observed for the geometric parameters (Table 1) and the NMR parameters (Tabs 3 & 4) before and after CO2 desorption. The C-O stretching vibrational IR spectra signal disappears at 2428.2 cm-1 due to CO2 desorption (Table 2). The second CO adsorbs on dopant with the distance between CO and OA of 3.105 Å. (Table 1). This process is an exothermic reaction with reaction heat of 0.10 eV (Fig. 4a). Geometrically, the bond lengths of Fe-B1 and Fe-B2 increase from 1.862 and 1.856 Å to 2.011 and 2.009 Å, respectively. While the Fe-B3 and Fe-OA bond lengths decrease from 2.443 and 1.735 Å to 2.011 and 1.618 Å, respectively (Table 1). However, the bond length and the IR spectra signal of CO (1.137 Å/2210.8 cm-1) in N-v are equal to that of gaseous CO molecules (1.138 Å/2210.7 cm-1), which are typical features of physical adsorption. CO adsorption leads to significant enhancement for σB1, σB2, σOA, J (Fe, B1), as well as notable decreasing for the σB3 and σFe (Tables 3 & 4 ). The approaching of the second CO to the dopant is accompanied by the departure of OA. The electron reorganization occurs with the conversion from quartet N-v to doublet N-vi. This is an exothermic process with the reaction heat of -1.56 eV (Fig. 4a). This conversion is verified by scanning the potential energy surfaces (PES) of both quartet N-v and doublet N-vi along with the Fe…C2 distance (Fig. 6 a). Along with the decreasing of Fe…C2 distance, the energy of N-v decreases first then increases distinctly until 2.263 Å (A point in Fig. 6a), where the energy of quartet N-v equals to that of doublet N-vi. Following the reduction of Fe…C2 distance, the PES of quartet N-v increases and the PES of doublet N-vi decreases. Therefore, the system changes from quartet to doublet when the Fe…C2 distance is shorter than 2.263 Å. Furthermore, this is an exothermic process with low energy barrier (0.03 eV) and the corresponding transition state structure is shown in Fig. (6 d). The contact distance of Fe…C2 decreases from 3.686 to 1.960 Å, and the bond length of Fe-OA increases from 1.618 to 1.899 Å, indicating the CO chemisorption nature. Accompanied with 0.2 NBO electron transfer from N-v to CO (Fig. 5a), the IR spectra signal of the C-O stretching vibration is red-shifted from 2210.8 cm-1 in N-v to 1958.2 cm-1 in N-vi (Table 2). The second CO2 molecule comes into being with the formation of new C2–OA bond, with a barrier of 0.76 eV. It is small enough to be overcome considering that the previous steps are all exothermic reaction with total reaction heat of -6.40 eV (Fig. 4a). This barrier is lower as compared to Pt1/FeOx (0.77 eV) [10], Pt-BN (1.31 eV) [70], and Pt/3N-graphene (1.41 eV) [71]. Geometrically, the distance of the generated CO2 with V N-Fe is 2.029 Å (Table 1), indicating their weak interaction. The C-O stretching mode is blue-shifted from 1958.2 cm-1 in N-vi to 2441.3 cm-1 in N-vii. Tabs 3 & 4 manifest outstanding increasing for σFe and J (Fe, OA), as well as notable decreasing for σOA and J (C2, OA). Finally, CO2 desorption recovers the catalyst with the reaction heat of 0.59 eV (Fig. 4a). The C-O stretching signal disappears owing to CO2 desorption (Table 2). In path 2, the second CO adsorbs on N-iii with the contact distance between CO and OA of 3.103 Å. Geometrically, the bond length of CO (1.138 Å) in 2N-iv is equal to that of gaseous CO molecules (1.138 Å), which is a feature of physical adsorption. The CO adsorption is an exothermic process with the reaction heat of -0.10 eV (Fig. 4b). As shown in Table 2, the C-O stretching signal locates at 2206.4 cm-1. The subsequent approaching of the second CO to V N-Fe is accompanied by the departure of OA. This is an exothermic process with the reaction heat of -0.69 eV (Fig. 4b). The C-O stretching vibration IR spectra signal is red-shifted from 2206.4 cm-1 in 2N-iv to 1800.8 cm-1 in 2N-v (Table 2). The transfer of OA to CO generates doublet 2N-vi with the reaction heat of -0.14 eV (Fig. 4b). Geometrically, the contact distance between the generated CO2 and Fe atom is 2.029 Å (Table 1). The broken of Fe-OA leads to the electron transfer from generated CO2 back to V N-Fe (Fig. 5b). Two generated CO2 molecules depart one by one from 2N-vi with the reaction heat of 0.15 and 0.59 eV, respectively (Fig. 4b). Tabs S1 & S2 show prominent increase for σB1, σB2, σB3, σFe, as well as notable decrease for J (Fe, B1), J (Fe, B2), and J (Fe, B3). CO Oxidation on V B-Fe The triplet O2 is adsorbed on the sextet V B-Fe template to form quartet B-i, initiating the entire CO oxidation reaction (Fig. 7 a). The O2 adsorption is an exothermic process by -1.03 eV (inset in Fig. 7a). Geometrically, the bond lengths of Fe-N is shortened by 0.26 ± 0.07 Å, and the lengths of the novel Fe-OA, Fe-OB, and OA-OB bonds are 1.921, 1.922, and 1.332 Å, respectively (Table 5 ), indicating the strong bound between Fe and h-BN. About 0.4 NBO electrons are transferred from the V B-Fe to O2 (Fig. 5c), and the negatively charged OA and OB atoms favor the subsequent CO adsorption. The O2 adsorption causes distinct enhancement of σN1, σN2, σN3, σFe, and J (Fe, N) (Tabs S3 & S4). The subsequent adsorption of CO generates B-ii with the distance between CO and O2 of 4.522 Å (Table 5). The effect on the geometrical parameters of B-i is slight. CO adsorption is weak, characterized by the small reaction heat (- 0.05 eV) (Fig. 7a) and slight NBO charge variation of CO (Fig. 5c). CO adsorption can be proved with the C-O stretching signal appeared at 2211.0 cm-1 (Table 6 ). The following OA transfers to CO and generates the doublet B-iii. The approaching of the CO to the dopant is accompanied by the departure of OA. The electron reorganization occurs with the conversion from quartet B-ii to doublet B-iii. The distribution of HOMO orbital during OA transfer indicates that electrons are transferred from O2 back to V B-Fe (Fig. S1a & S1b). This is a significant exothermic process with the reaction heat of 3.47 eV (Fig. 7a). This conversion is verified by scanning the PES of both quartet B-ii and doublet B-iii along with the Fe…OA distance (Fig. 6b). Along with the increasing of Fe…OA distance, the energy of B-ii increases distinctly until 2.567 Å (B point in Fig. 7b), where the energy of quartet B-ii equals to that of doublet B-iii. Therefore, the system changes from quartet to doublet when the Fe…OA distance is 2.567 Å. Furthermore, this process needs to overcome an activation energy barrier of 1.88 eV (Fig. 7a), indicating that the first oxygen transfer is difficult for V B-Fe and the corresponding transition state structure is shown in Fig. (6 e). The contact distance of Fe…OA increases from 1.92 to 3.77 Å and C1…OA distance decreases from 4.522 to 1.171 Å, indicating the chemisorption nature. There are about 0.54 electrons transferred to OA atom from the adsorbed CO molecule (Fig. 5c), implying their strong interaction. The IR spectrum of C-O stretching is blue-shifted by 221 cm-1 from 2211.0 cm-1 in B-ii to 2432.0 cm-1 in B-iii (Table 6). The negatively charged OB is beneficial for the approaching of the second CO molecule and succeeded oxidation reaction. Two possible mechanisms are discussed for the following steps: In path 1, the first CO2 desorption is an endothermic reaction with reaction heat of 0.10 eV (Fig. 5a). No significant change is observed for the geometrical and NMR parameters upon CO2 desorption. The C-O stretching vibrational signal disappears at 2432.0 cm-1 owing to CO2 desorption (Table 6). The subsequent second CO adsorbs on B-iv to form B-v with the reaction energy of -0.08 eV (Fig. 7a). Geometrically, the large contact distance between CO and OB is 3.174 Å (Table 5). However, the bond length of CO (1.137 Å) in B-v is equal to that of gaseous CO molecules (1.138 Å), which is a feature of physical adsorption. The IR spectra signal of C-O stretching vibrational appears at 2214.3 cm-1 in B-v (Table 6), which is equal to that of gaseous CO molecules (2210.7 cm-1). The approaching of the second CO to the dopant is accompanied by the departure of OB. The electron reorganization occurs with the conversion from doublet B-v to sextet B-vi. Distributions of their HOMO orbitals are shown in Fig. S1c & S1d. This is a significant exothermic process with the reaction heat of -1.72 eV (Fig. 7a). This conversion is verified by scanning the PES of both doublet B-v and sextet B-vi along with the C2…OB distance (Fig. 6c). Along with the decreasing of C2…OB distance, the energy of B-v increases distinctly until 1.906 Å (C point in Fig. 6c), where the energy of doublet B-v equals to that of sextet B-vi. Following the reduction of C2…OB distance, the PES of doublet B-v increases and the PES of sextet B-vi drops. Therefore, the system changes from doublet to sextet when the C2…OB distance is 1.906 Å. Furthermore, the previous steps are all extremely exothermic reactions with reaction heat of -4.53 eV and a moderate barrier of 0.76 eV for OB transfer is easily to be overcome (Fig. 7a). The corresponding transition state structure is shown in Fig. (6 f). The contact distance of C2…OB decreases from 3.174 to 1.178 Å, and the bond length of Fe-OB increases from 1.559 to 2.287 Å, indicating the CO chemisorption nature. Along with OB transfer, 0.17 electrons are transferred to OB from V B-Fe (Fig. 5c). Tab S3 shows significantly decrease for the σ of N1, N2, N3, Fe, and OB. The IR spectrum of C-O stretching mode is blue-shifted by 230 cm-1 from 2214.3 cm-1 in B-v to 2444.4 cm-1 in B-vi (Table 6). Finally, CO2 desorption from B-vi back to V B-Fe is an endothermic reaction of 0.39 eV (Fig. 7a). This desorption influences slightly to the geometrical and NMR parameters. There are 0.4 NBO electrons transferred from OB back to V B-Fe (Fig. 5c). The C-O stretching signal disappears at 2444.4 cm-1 (Table 6) owing to CO2 desorption. In path 2, the second CO is adsorbed on B-iii by interaction with OB (Fig. 5b) before desorption of generated CO2. The physisorption characteristics of this CO is described by small reaction heat (-0.08 eV) (Fig. 7b) and large contact distance (3.246 Å) between CO with OB (Table 5). The subsequent approaching of the second CO to V B-Fe is accompanied by the departure of OB. The bond length of C2-OB prominently decreases from 3.246 to 1.301 Å (Table 5), indicating the chemisorption feature on B-iv. This is an endothermic process with the reaction heat of 0.05 eV (Fig. 7b). There are 0.42 NBO electrons transferring from OB to CO, leading to significant increase of C2 NBO charge. The C-O stretching mode is red-shifted from 2212.0 cm-1 in 2B-iv to 1881.4 cm-1 in 2B-v (Table 6). Tabs S5 & S6 show slightly decrease for σN1, σN2, σN3, and notable increasing for J (Fe, N1), J (Fe, N2), and J (Fe, N3) owing to the formation of OCO. The following OB is transferred to CO to generate sextet 2B-vi with the reaction heat of -1.81 eV (Fig. 7b). Finally, two CO2 desorption from 2B-vi to V B-Fe are endothermic reactions by 0.14 and 0.40 eV, respectively (Fig. 7b). Furthermore, the effect on the NMR and geometrical parameters is slight. The IR spectra signal of C-O stretching vibrational at 2448.4 cm-1 disappears due to CO2 desorption (Table 6). Conclusions In summary, Fe-adsorbed hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) SACs are investigated for the catalytic CO oxidation by DFT approach. The CO oxidation process mainly includes O2 adsorption, electron reorganization, CO adsorption, oxygen transfer, and CO2 desorption. Due to the stability of h-BN, the enhanced catalytic activity of Fe-adsorbed h-BN is mainly attributed to the strong hybridization between the electronic states of O2 and adsorbed single Fe atom. The first step for CO oxidation should be O2 adsorption, instead of CO, and the rate-limiting step is the first oxygen transfer to generate CO2. In addition, V N-Fe and V B-Fe SACs exhibit extremely high stability and activity during CO oxidation. The weak interaction between generated CO2 and V N-Fe/ V B-Fe can effectively prompt the CO2 desorption, allowing the Fe active site for next catalytic cycle. The energy barrier of V N-Fe for CO oxidation is lower than that of V B-Fe under mild condition, indicating that V N-Fe SAC is a potential efficient catalyst for CO oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Conversion of CO into CO2 is a prototypical reaction in heterogeneous catalysis and is extensively studied to explore the underlying mechanisms of related reaction. A detailed mechanism exploration was carried out for CO oxidation catalyzed by single Fe atom adsorbed hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) at room temperature. DFT calculations demonstrate the enhancement of catalytic activity of h-BN for CO oxidation upon Fe-adsorbing. The substitution of iron significantly decreases the energy difference between the HOMO and LUMO in h-BN. The positively charged Fe atom in dopant favors the capture of O2 molecule and serves as the catalytic active site for CO oxidation reaction. Energetically, the adsorbed Fe atom prefers to reside in N vacancy (V N-Fe) rather than B vacancy, with the energy barriers for the generation of two CO2 molecules are 1.18 eV and 0.76 eV, respectively. The rate determining step is the first oxygen transfer, as attributes to the significant charge transfer from Fe-adsorbed h-BN to O2. The enhanced catalytic activity implies that Fe-adsorbed h-BN has potential application for the development of low-cost, non-toxic monoatomic catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced catalytic activity for CO oxidation by Fe-Adsorbing on BN under mild condition: A promising single-atom catalyst
